title: American Service Member Among the Injured, Pentagon Says
content:
One American service member and his family were injured in the attacks, according to Defense Department officials. No specifics were released.

“Due to privacy concerns, we are not releasing the status of their injuries at this time,” the United States European Command said in a written statement. “We are also working closely with our interagency partners and host-nation counterparts to determine the appropriate steps to ensure the safety and security of all U.S. personnel.”

title: Condolences From Two Sides in Syria Conflict
content: In Syria, where the Islamic State was incubated during the civil war, both the government and opposition denounced the attacks and offered condolences. The High Negotiations Committee, which is representing a constellation of opposition and rebel groups at peace talks in Geneva, said in a statement that it condemned the attack “in the strongest terms.” “The world must stand united to defeat terrorism,” said the group’s spokesman, Salem al-Meslet. “It is with a heavy heart we learned of these ruthless attacks in Brussels. The H.N.C. and people of Syria stand with the people of Belgium in solidarity.” The state-run Syrian news agency, SANA, quoted an unnamed Foreign Ministry official who condemned the attacks, but also put the blame on its opponents in the West, calling the violence “an inevitable consequence of the wrong policies and of tolerance for terrorism.” President Bashar al-Assad has portrayed himself as a lonely figure in the fight against international terrorism and criticized the United States and its Arab allies for trying to distinguish between "moderate" groups and more extreme elements, saying there is nothing to choose between. The United States and its allies have supported insurgents they consider relatively moderate, including groups that oppose both Islamic State and Mr. Assad. For its part, the opposition has argued that Mr. Assad allowed the Islamic State to flourish while stamping out more moderate opponents, so he could present the world with a choice between himself and the extremist group. The Lebanese militant group Hezbollah, which has been fighting in Syria on the side of the government, also condemned the attacks, blaming countries it said supported terrorism and extremists like Islamic State that accuse other Muslims, especially the Shiites that form Hezbollah’s base, of apostasy. “Everyone in the world now realizes who the source and financier of this problem is, but regardless, the major global powers still give support and protection to those countries who sponsor and export terrorism,” the group said in a statement issued by its media office. It appeared to be pointing at Saudi Arabia. Saudi Arabia, an American ally, says it backs insurgent groups in Syria but not the Islamic State or the Qaeda-linked Nusra Front, which are considered terrorist groups by the United States and others. Saudi Arabia's regional rival, Iran, sponsors Hezbollah, which the United States also lists as a terrorist organization. But in a sign of the tangled alliances in the battle against ISIS, Hezbollah views the Islamic State as an existential threat. While Arab and Muslim governments around the world lined up to condemn the attacks, they were condemned by Islamic State’s admirers. Anne Barnard reported from Beirut, and Maher Samaan from Paris. Reporting was contributed by Hwaida Saad in Beirut and Karam Shoumali in Istanbul.

title: Airports May Tighten Security
content:
[nytmedia id="100000004286024" crop="592" type="image"]


The shutdown of the Brussels Airport could affect as many as 55,000 travelers a day, for as long as it lasts. But it is unlikely to cause major disruptions to international air traffic. 

That is little solace, though, to the airport’s chief executive, Arnaud Feist. Tuesday’s bombings were “without doubt the blackest day’’ in Brussels Airport’s 76-year history, he said.

 Mr. Feist indicated that the airport would remain closed on Wednesday to allow time for the police investigations and to assess the extensive damage to the  departures hall. 

The main impact, analysts said, could be a tightening of security measures at other, bigger airports.

Brussels Airport is served by a number of long-haul carriers from the Persian Gulf, North America and Africa and is a hub for the Star Alliance airline grouping – which includes Lufthansa, United Airlines and Singapore Airlines. Yet  it ranks only 21st among Europe’s 30 largest airports by number of passengers, according to ACI Europe, an airport lobby group. Its 23 million passengers a year are far below the numbers at major hubs like London Heathrow, Paris Charles de Gaulle or Frankfurt Airport. 

Analysts said the relatively modest volume of flights that might be affected over the coming days could potentially be rerouted to larger airports in cities like Amsterdam or Paris. But some expressed concern that the attacks might set off  new security clampdowns at larger airports – changes that would have greater repercussions for travelers.

“This appears to have happened in a check-in area that’s open to anyone,’’ said David Feldman, the managing partner at Exambela, an aviation consulting firm based in Lausanne, Switzerland. "So the question is, do you create a response to that?"

If airports, for example, were to introduce security checks outside the airport or start limiting airport access to ticket-holders only, “that could be extremely disruptive,’’ Mr. Feldman said.

title: Photos of Brussels Suspects Confirmed
content: [nytmedia id="100000004285910" crop="592" type="image"] The three men in this photo have been identified as suspects in the Brussels airport bombings, and authorities are asking for help to identify the man on the right in the light-colored jacket. The two men on the left wearing dark-colored tops "are believed to have been suicide bombers," said Eric Van der Sijpt, a spokesman for the Belgian federal prosecutor's office. The Brussels police posted a second photo on Facebook and Twitter of one of the suspects and have also issued a wanted notice for him. [nytmedia id="100000004285925" crop="190" type="image"] “The police is seeking to identify this man,” the authorities said in a statement. Taken together, the comments from the police and the prosecutor's office suggest that two of the men are dead and the wanted suspect might be at large, but authorities have not confirmed that outright. “For the time being, I can only confirm that this is a picture of three suspects,” said Mr. Van der Sijp. Given that the two suspects on the left have been identified as suicide bombers, some have looked to photo for additional clues. Both men appear to be wearing a gloves on their left hands. Some on social media are speculating that it could have been an effort to disguise detonators. Two bombs were detonated at the airport and a third was found unexploded after the attacks. It remains unknown if the third suspected was carrying that device.

The Brussels police posted a second photo on Facebook and Twitter of one of the suspects and have also issued a wanted notice for him.

“The police is seeking to identify this man,” the authorities said in a statement.

title: Websites Allow Facebook Users to Put Belgian Flag Over Profile Photos
content: Facebook has not yet rolled out an overlay of the Belgium flag for profile photos, but people aren't waiting. Multiple websites are providing directions for Facebook users who want to express solidarity with the attack victims by using the overlays. They first became popular last summer as a way to show support for same-sex marriage. The social network added a photo filter of the French flag after the terrorist attacks in Paris last fall, as well. https://twitter.com/MyAltardLife/status/712272097762934784 But the current trend isn't without its critics. https://twitter.com/D_Callahan_/status/712303780579164160 https://twitter.com/_pragyaa/status/712296537192148993
content_expanded:
Facebook has not yet rolled out an overlay of the Belgium flag for profile photos, but people aren’t waiting.

Multiple websites are providing directions for Facebook users who want to express solidarity with the attack victims by using the overlays.

The social network added a photo filter of the French flag after the terrorist attacks in Paris last fall, as well.

title: Belgium to Begin 3 Days of National Mourning
content:
Jan Jambon, a deputy prime minister and the interior minister of Belgium, has announced that the country will be in a state of mourning for three days. 

The mourning period starts today, said his spokeswoman, Anne-Laure Mouligneaux. 

Countries around the world have expressed solidarity with Belgium. 

President François Hollande of France directed flags to be flown at half-staff.   On Tuesday night, the Eiffel Tower is to be lit in red and yellow, which along with black are the colors of Belgium's national flag. 

A Belgian flag was raised atop No. 10 Downing Street, the residence of the British prime minister.  

King Philippe of Belgium was scheduled to address the nation at 7 p.m. local time.

title: Brussels Hospitals Are Prepared, Health Minister Says
content:
Belgium's health minister, Maggie De Block, said at a news conference that a disaster response plan had been activated in hospitals in and around Brussels.

"In total, 14 hospitals are receiving wounded," she said. "Patients are still coming in." She said that there was enough capacity and that the hospitals were prepared.

Renaud Mazy, the managing director of a Brussels-area hospital that admitted 11 people from the terrorist attacks on Tuesday, discussed how his facility had planned for the emergency.

title: German State Tightens Border With Belgium
content:
The authorities in North Rhine-Westphalia, the German state next to Belgium, announced tighter controls on the border on Tuesday after the Brussels attacks.

The state's interior minister, Ralf Jäger, leveled unusual public criticism at his Belgian colleagues in making the announcement.

Jihadists  have made inroads in the Brussels community of Molenbeek and "one should possibly have acted sooner," Mr. Jäger told reporters in Düsseldorf, the state capital.

He expressed surprise and shock that an extensive terrorist cell could have existed for years in Belgium.

"It's not a question of individual actors organizing themselves — on the contrary, the mode of action was structured and agreed," Mr. Jäger said. "That presumes the formation of a cell."

"It is easier to find such cells than radicalized lone actors," the minister added. "And that is what is frightening: that such a cell could not be discovered."

Mr. Jäger later said that the Belgian security services had sharply improved in recent months and had exerted considerable pressure on the extremists, but his comments were met with some derision.

Armin Laschet, leader of the Christian Democrat opposition to the Social Democrat state government, said Mr. Jäger would do better to keep quiet. 

Mr. Jäger is under fire for the failures in policing that contributed to the chaos on New Year's Eve in Cologne, where hundreds of German women reported being assaulted by hundreds of men who appeared to be  migrants.
